My dear Daubeny, Please refer to your letter No, 394-19/8 of the 27th of January, 2. The enclosure to my Printed Letter No.C/117 of the 24th of January 194^ and paragraphs 21(i), 183, and 226 of my Intelligence Summaries for 1944 dealt with this 'excellent fuel'. The coke is of very high calorific value and burns with a clear flame but has the disadvantage of eventually destroying the iron basket or grate which is used as a container. It is sold by the Bahrain Petroleum Company at Rs,10/- a ton with an additional charge of Re.l/- each bag which is used returnable on the return of the bag. A further charge of Rs.10/- a ton is levied to cover the cost of transport of coke to Manama. I am sending a bag of coke as a free-will offering. If you desire any further information I feel sure both Rogers and Hadow will be able to help for both of them have first-hand knowledge of the product. Yours sincrely, Id/- T.H 3-2-4f. .G. physicalDescription.extent: The documents in the file are arranged in chronological order. There are notes at the end of the file (folios 13-14). The notes refer to documents within the file; they give a brief description of the correspondence with a reference number in blue or red crayon, which refers back to that correspondence in the file.

The foliation is written in pencil, and can be found in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. The numbering commences at the front cover with 1, 1A and 1B and then it carries on until 16, which is the last number on the back cover of the file.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence between the Bahrain Petroleum Company Limited (BAPCO) representative, the Political Agent at Bahrain and the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf on the exportation and use of Bahraini coal and coke.
